channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Virus Response Widens Political Divide in Swing States
item.description: A whistle-blower told a House subcommittee that the administration was too slow in preparing for the pandemic. Even talking can propel the droplets that spread the virus, a study suggests. Senator Richard M. Burr stepped aside as the Intelligence Committee chairman during an F.B.I. review of his stock sales amid the outbreak.

item.title: Breonna Taylor Police Shooting: Governor Orders Review of Louisville Raid
item.description: The police said officers shot and killed Breonna Taylor, 26, in a March raid after her boyfriend shot an officer in the leg.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old emergency medical technician, was killed when the police raided her apartment in Louisville, Ky., in March. She was not a target of their investigation.

item.title: Thousands Are Headed to Alaska’s Fishing Towns. So Is the Coronavirus.
item.description: As the famed Copper River salmon season begins, isolated fishing towns are bracing for an influx of workers and their first brush with the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: The community in Cordova, Alaska, like other fishing towns in the state, is polarized. Fishing is its lifeblood, but many wonder how many coronavirus cases it can afford.

item.title: Coronavirus Lockdowns: Businesses Turn to Armed Defiance
item.description: Armed militia-style protesters have helped businesses across Texas defy coronavirus lockdowns and reopen. Protesters say they are enforcing the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
item.media:credit: Eli Hartman/Odessa American, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An armed protester provided support to the owner of a bar in Odessa, Texas, which reopened last week in defiance of an order that it remain shut.

item.title: McDonald’s Details What Dining In Will Look Like
item.description: The fast-food chain distributed a guide to franchise owners with instructions like putting “closed” signs on tables to promote social-distancing and cleaning bathrooms every half-hour.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Leah Frances for The New York Times
item.media:description: Individual franchise owners will have some discretion on when to reopen their locations.

item.title: Coronavirus May Pose a New Risk to Younger Patients: Strokes
item.description: Doctors have reported a flurry of cases in Covid-19 patients — including a healthy 27-year-old emergency medical technician in Queens. After a month in the hospital, he is learning to walk again.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

item.title: E.P.A. Opts Against Limits on Water Contaminant Tied to Fetal Damage
item.description: A new E.P.A. policy on perchlorate, which is used in rocket fuel, would revoke a 2011 finding that the chemical should be regulated.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Andrew Wheeler, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, on Capitol Hill in March.

item.title: To Fight Waste and Hunger, Food Banks Start Cooking
item.description: As farmers throw away produce and other Americans line up for food, relief groups are connecting the two by turning those ingredients into meals.
item.dc:creator: Brett Anderson
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leandra Forman, left, and Hannah Arvin in the kitchen at FoodChain in Lexington, Ky., one of several relief groups around the country cooking meals to feed the hungry.

item.title: Appeals Court Allows Emoluments Suit Against Trump to Proceed
item.description: The court rejected the president’s request to dismiss a case brought by the State of Maryland and the District of Columbia regarding his Washington hotel.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:description: Maryland and the District of Columbia are arguing that the president’s interest in his Washington hotel violates the Constitution’s bans on accepting benefits from state or foreign governments.

item.title: On Politics: Stay at Home? States Can’t Agree
item.description: A governor’s order is overturned as a virus-era fight heats up: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, Michael Flynn, Federal Reserve: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Social distancing at the Washougal Waterfront Park in Washington state.

item.title: Meat Plant Closures Mean Pigs Are Gassed or Shot Instead
item.description: Coronavirus outbreaks at meatpacking plants have created a backlog of animals ready for slaughter but with nowhere to go. Farmers are having to cull them.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery and David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Piglets are crowded in a nursery at Greg Boerboom’s farm in Marshall, Minn.

item.title: As Unemployment Soars, Lawmakers Push to Cover Workers’ Wages
item.description: Progressive and conservative lawmakers are increasingly pushing for the government to guarantee workers’ incomes, signaling how profoundly the economic debate has shifted during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Waiting to file for unemployment in Fayetteville, Ark. The idea of guaranteed income programs is gaining support on both ends of the political spectrum.

item.title: Hotels vs. Airbnb: Has Covid-19 Disrupted the Disrupter?
item.description: For years, home sharing has put pressure on hotel rates and occupancy levels. Social distancing, hygiene and refund policies may be the new game changers.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Trump White House Changes Its Story on Michael Flynn
item.description: Three years ago, President Trump swiftly fired his first national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, for lying to the F.B.I. Ahead of the November election, Mr. Trump and his allies are now telling a very different tale.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, pleaded guilty to lying to F.B.I. investigators.

item.title: Coronavirus Could Create a Hodgepodge of Campus Life in the Fall
item.description: The nation’s largest public university system will stay online, but other colleges are determined to bring back students. The patchwork could look much like the rest of the country.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:description: A graduate on the empty campus of San Diego State University. Remote learning will continue in the fall, students learned this week.

item.title: Unemployment Claims Show More Jobs Are Vanishing: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange last week.

item.title: Live Coronavirus World News Updates
item.description: The pandemic will claim millions of indirect victims, the U.N. says, by blocking vaccinations and other medical care. It is reaching into some of the world’s most vulnerable communities, in places like Bangladesh and Yemen.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paris in April. The World Health Organization warned on Thursday of a looming mental illness crisis, the result of “the isolation, the fear, the uncertainty, the economic turmoil,” brought on by the pandemic.

item.title: TikTok Broke Privacy Promises, Children’s Groups Say
item.description: Twenty consumer groups said the video app had failed to make some changes it agreed to carry out last year to settle federal charges.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: TikTok is under scrutiny by consumer groups.

item.title: Michigan Barber Karl Manke Has Licenses Suspended
item.description: State officials said Karl Manke’s decision to reopen his shop during the coronavirus pandemic jeopardized public health and safety.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Karl Manke, who faces two misdemeanor charges for reopening his barbershop despite state shutdown orders, cut a client’s hair at the shop on Tuesday.

item.title: Cycle of Arrests Leads Woman to Jail at a Dangerous Time
item.description: After failing to appear in court on traffic and other charges, a pregnant woman was detained overnight at a Montgomery, Ala., jail, where a coronavirus outbreak has occurred.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Diamond Davis, who is in her first trimester of pregnancy, said she spent a night in a jail cell in April with a woman who was coughing during the night.

item.title: Trump Administration Plans to Extend Virus Border Restrictions Indefinitely
item.description: Orders that have effectively sealed the United States to migrants seeking protection from persecution would remain in place until a health official declared the virus no longer a threat.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: The Trump administration has used the public health authority to immediately return more than 20,000 migrants to since the rule was implemented in late March.

item.title: Trump Pointedly Criticizes Fauci for His Testimony to Congress
item.description: “He wants to play all sides of the equation,” the president said of the nation’s top infectious disease expert.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci has become a target of critics who see him as undermining the president’s efforts to restore the economy and as exaggerating the effects of the pandemic.

item.title: Judge in Flynn Case Renowned for His Independent Streak
item.description: U.S. District Court Judge Emmet Sullivan will hear a challenge to the Justice Department’s surprise move to drop charges against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Judge Emmet G. Sullivan was first appointed to the bench by President Ronald Reagan.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: More Americans are leave their homes, even in states that haven’t reopened yet.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Trump Picks Ex-Drug Company Executive to Lead Accelerated Coronavirus Vaccine Effort
item.description: The chief operating officer will be an Army general who specializes in logistics.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: Moncef Slaoui before the House Oversight and Government Reform committee hearing on the diabetes drug Avandia in 2007.

item.title: Republicans Release Names of Obama-Era Officials in ‘Unmaskings’ That Revealed Flynn
item.description: The moves prompted accusations that President Trump’s allies were disclosing the information for his political benefit.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department moved last week to drop a false-statements criminal case against Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser.

item.title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Says Coronavirus Shutdown Is Overreach
item.description: The decision, by a 4-to-3 majority, was a high-profile challenge of the emergency authority of a statewide official during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: A protest against the coronavirus shutdown in front of the State Capitol in Madison, Wis., in late April.

item.title: Michael Flynn Case: Judge Appoints Outsider to Take On Justice Dept.
item.description: A retired judge will also examine whether the former national security adviser committed perjury.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, in 2017 in Washington.

item.title: Charges Against Former Michigan State President Are Dismissed
item.description: A judge said prosecutors had failed to prove that Lou Anna K. Simon knew of sexual abuse committed by Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar when he was employed by the university.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: Lou Anna K. Simon, a former president of Michigan State University, in 2018.

item.title: New Inflammatory Condition in Children Probably Linked to Coronavirus, Study Finds
item.description: Researchers compared 10 cases in Italy with previous cases of a similar childhood illness, Kawasaki disease. The rate of the new cases was much higher, and the conditions were more serious.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:description: Medical staff tending to a coronavirus patient in the I.C.U. of the Papa Giovanni XXIII Hospital in Bergamo, Italy. The hospital’s pediatric center saw 10 cases of the inflammatory condition in just two months.

item.title: Running Your First Race Indoors
item.description: Here’s what life is like for a teacher who’s making her first run for office amid the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Ex-F.B.I. Official Is Said to Undercut Justice Dept. Effort to Drop Flynn Case
item.description: Prosecutors questioned a former F.B.I. official whose notes were used to buttress their motion to dismiss the charge against the president’s first national security adviser.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Bill Priestap, a former top F.B.I. official, played a central role in the agency’s 2016 investigation into Russia’s efforts to interfere in the presidential election.

item.title: Utah Lowers Penalty for Polygamy, No Longer a Felony
item.description: An amendment that went into effect this week allows polygamy to be punished as an infraction in some cases, but it remains a felony if force, threats or other abuses are involved.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A group of pro-polygamy demonstrators at the Utah State Capitol in Salt Lake City in 2017.
